column4: hey guys ... i am trying to get my ipod running with ubuntu. i found a kernel module which seems to work fine... but i don't know what the author means with "location of your linux tree" in the following line: make -C <the location of your linuxtree> M=`pwd` modules
??? Kernel modules? What instructions are you following and what is your ubuntu version?
instructions are here http://de.pastebin.ca/931871, 2.6.22-14-generic, ubuntu 7.10
qos and what program are you using to manage your music? Rythmbox, exaile, amarok?
oh, qos_ You said " i am trying to get my ipod running with ubuntu", but you really want to get your iphone going.
no ipod touch ...
Well, you pasted instructions about a kernel module that charges and iphone when plugged into your computer.
thats my problem at the moment ...  it is not recharing with linux
But you have an ipod touch. Not an iphone qos_ What makes you think that will work?
the module is for the ipod touch
you can see the project details here ... http://matt.colyer.name/projects/iphone-module/
So let me get this straight. You've got an ipod touch, which you have working with ubuntu. The only thing that isn't working, is that it doesn't charge when connected. Is that right?
right :) ... and for this there is a module or i think they call it driver
Did you follow these instructions to get it working? https://help.ubuntu.com/community/PortableDevices/iPhone
yeah
Ok... well, at least I'm up to speed now if not very helpful. :P And what was the problem with the instructions, they didn't work?
i don't understand what the location of my linux tree is...
I don't know either.
are you familiar with compiling?
I can follow instructions. And I used to compile my own kernel back in the dapper days, but no more. Aside from that kernel tree thing though, it doesn't look too hard.
Try just asking about that single line qos_
didn't start this whole thing with my question about that single line? ;)
Yup. But because you said "my ipod" I was concerned you were doing something really wrong. I just wanted to make sure you weren't a noob following bad advice.
